Program Documentation¶

functions module¶

functions.cal_income(coeffs)¶

Calculating income over age by age polynomials

Parameters:coeffs – DataFrame, containing coefficients of the age polynomials for all 3 education groups
Returns:array, income from age 22 to 65 for education group {AltDeg}
functions.exp_val(inc_with_shk_tran, exp_inc_shk_perm, savings_incr, grid_coh, v, weight, age, flag)¶

Calculate the expected value of the backward cumulative utility within the working period using Gaussian Quadrature and Cubic Spline Interpolation

Parameters:
  • inc_with_shk_tran – array with size 3-by-1, income with transitory shock
  • exp_inc_shk_perm – array with size 3-by-1, exponentiated permanent income shock
  • savings_incr – array with size N_C-by-1, savings increment
  • grid_coh – array with size (N_COH, ), grid of cash-on-hand
  • v – array with size (N_COH, ), backward cumulative utility(value function)
  • weight – array with size 3-by-1, weight from Gaussian Quadrature
  • age – int, actual age
  • flag – string, flag var to choose adding details of ISA or Loan or nothing(just the original model)
Returns:

float64, expected value of the backward cumulative utility
functions.exp_val_r(inc, exp_inc_shk_perm, savings_incr, grid_coh, v, weight)¶

Calculate the expected value of the backward cumulative utility within the retirement period using Gaussian Quadrature and Cubic Spline Interpolation

Parameters:
  • inc – float64, deterministic component at certain retirement age
  • exp_inc_shk_perm – array with size 3-by-1, exponentiated permanent income shock
  • savings_incr – array with size N_C-by-1, savings increment
  • grid_coh – array with size (N_COH, ), grid of cash-on-hand
  • v – array with size (N_COH, ), backward cumulative utility(value function)
  • weight – array with size 3-by-1, weight from Gaussian Quadrature
Returns:

float64, expected value of the backward cumulative utility
functions.read_input_data(income_fp, mortal_fp)¶

Read data - Income(coefficients of age polynomials), Income Shocks(std), Survival Probability(conditional prob)

Parameters:
  • income_fp – file path of the income data
  • mortal_fp – file path of the survival prob data
Returns:

age_coeff: DataFrame, containing coefficients of the age polynomials for all 3 education groups std: DataFrame, two groups of income shocks cond_prob: DataFrame, conditional survival prob from age 21 to 100
functions.utility(C, gamma)¶

Constant Relative Risk Aversion - Utility Function

Parameters:
  • C – array or scalar, consumption
  • gamma – scalar, risk preference parameter
Returns:

array or scalar, utility

dp module¶

dp.dp_solver(income, income_ret, sigma_perm_shock, sigma_tran_shock, prob, *, flag='orig')¶

Solve for the policy rules (a.k.a consumption functions) using the backward induction method from the perspective of Dynamic Programming

Parameters:
  • income – array with size of (44,), deterministic component income over the working period
  • income_ret – float64, income at the last working period
  • sigma_perm_shock – float64, standard deviation of the permanent shock in the log term
  • sigma_tran_shock – float64, standard deviation of the transitory shock in the log term
  • prob – array with size of (78,), conditional survival probability
  • flag – string, flag var to choose adding details of ISA or Loan or nothing(just the original model)
Returns:

c_collection: DataFrame, consumption functions from age 100 to 22 v_collection: DataFrame, value functions from age 100 to 22

cal_ce module¶

cal_ce.c_func(c_df, COH, age)¶

Given the consumption functions and cash-on-hand at certain age, calculate the corresponding consumption using the cubic spline interpolation

Parameters:
  • c_df – DataFrame, consumption functions from age 100 to 22
  • COH – array, cash-on-hand in every possible scenario
  • age – scalar
Returns:

array with same size as COH, consumption
cal_ce.cal_certainty_equi(prob, c)¶

Calculate consumption CE and wealth CE

Parameters:
  • prob – array with size of (78,), conditional survival probability
  • c – array with size of , consumption process
Returns:

c_ce: float64, consumption CE total_w_ce: float64, total wealth CE
cal_ce.generate_consumption_process(income_bf_ret, sigma_perm_shock, sigma_tran_shock, c_func_df, *, flag='orig')¶

Simulate the consumption process and income process

Parameters:
  • income_bf_ret – array with size of (44,), deterministic component of income over the working period
  • sigma_perm_shock – float64, standard deviation of the permanent shock in the log term
  • sigma_tran_shock – float64, standard deviation of the transitory shock in the log term
  • c_func_df – DataFrame, consumption functions from age 100 to 22
  • flag – string, flag var to choose adding details of ISA or Loan or nothing(just the original model)
Returns:

c: array with size of N_SIM-by-79, consumption process inc: array with size of N_SIM-by-79, income process
